Approximate and Weighted Data Reconstruction Attack in Federated Learning

Ziqi Wang †
ziqi.wang@fau.de
&Yongcun Song  
yongcun.song@fau.de
&Enrique Zuazua †   
enrique.zuazua@fau.de
Corresponding author.Chair for Dynamics, Control, Machine Learning and Numerics – Alexander von Humboldt Professorship, Department of Mathematics, Friedrich-Alexander-Universität Erlangen-Nürnberg, Cauerstrasse 11, 91058 Erlangen, Germany.Chair of Computational Mathematics, Fundación Deusto Avda. de las Universidades 24, 48007 Bilbao, Basque Country, Spain.Departamento de Matemáticas, Universidad Autónoma de Madrid, 28049 Madrid, Spain.
Abstract

Federated Learning (FL) is a distributed learning paradigm that enables multiple clients to collaborate on building a machine learning model without sharing their private data. Although FL is considered privacy-preserved by design, recent data reconstruction attacks demonstrate that an attacker can recover clients’ training data based on the parameters shared in FL. However, most existing methods fail to attack the most widely used horizontal Federated Averaging (FedAvg) scenario, where clients share model parameters after multiple local training steps. To tackle this issue, we propose an interpolation-based approximation method, which makes attacking FedAvg scenarios feasible by generating the intermediate model updates of the clients’ local training processes. Then, we design a layer-wise weighted loss function to improve the data quality of reconstruction. We assign different weights to model updates in different layers concerning the neural network structure, with the weights tuned by Bayesian optimization. Finally, experimental results validate the superiority of our proposed approximate and weighted attack (AWA) method over the other state-of-the-art methods, as demonstrated by the substantial improvement in different evaluation metrics for image data reconstructions.

1 Introduction

With the increasing volume of data generated by distributed personal electronic devices and organizations, traditional centralized approaches for training machine learning models face challenges in terms of data collection, privacy concerns, and scalability. To address them, Federated Learning (FL) li2020federated ; mcmahan2023communicationefficient has emerged as a promising paradigm and has gained significant attention in recent years.

One prominent feature of FL is its ability to facilitate model training on distributed data sources owned by individual clients while keeping the data localized and exchanging only model updates. For example, in the most commonly used Federated Averaging (FedAvg) mcmahan2023communicationefficient algorithm, each client trains its local model with its private data and shares the updated model parameters to a server, where the model parameters are aggregated and used to update the global model. In other words, FL enables multiple participants to build a common and robust machine learning model without sharing data, thus addressing critical issues such as data privacy, data security, and data access rights. FL has gained significant attention in recent years to handle the growing amount of data and the increasing concerns about privacy in a number of applications, such as healthcare brisimi2018federated ; xu2021federated , and learning a controller model across several autonomous vehicles without sharing their history trajectories zeng2022federated .

Although it was widely believed that model updates in FL are safe to share, recent studies geng2023improved ; xu2022agic ; yin2021see ; zhu2019deep have shown that clients’ sensitive training data can be compromised through data reconstruction attacks zhu2019deep . In these attacks, the adversary randomly initializes dummy samples and labels, and executes forward and backward propagation to obtain dummy model updates. Through an iterative process of minimizing the discrepancy between the dummy model updates and the shared ones, the dummy samples and labels are updated simultaneously. In the literature, some work has already been done for improving the reconstruction performance, we refer to the label inference techniques in yin2021see ; zhao2020idlg , the new distance functions and optimizers in geiping2020inverting ; wang2020sapag , and the regularization methods in geiping2020inverting ; jeon2021gradient ; wei2020framework .

By inferring labels in advance, the joint optimization of both samples and labels can be avoided, thus reducing the complexity of the optimization problem. It was first discovered in zhao2020idlg that the label information of a single sample can be analytically extracted based on the model updates of the last fully connected layer. Later, yin2021see extended the single sample label extraction to batch samples, under the limiting assumption of non-repeating labels in the batch. The above limitation is further addressed by the batch label inference approach proposed in geng2023improved .

To measure the discrepancy between the dummy and shared gradients, the Euclidean distance is commonly used in the loss function for the attack, see yin2021see ; zhao2020idlg ; zhu2019deep . Moreover, the angle-based cosine similarity was suggested in geiping2020inverting ; xu2022agic since the high-dimensional direction of the gradients carries more information than the magnitude. In wang2020sapag , a Gaussian kernel of gradients differences was proposed to measure the discrepancy, allowing the scaling factor in the kernel to be adapted to the distribution of gradients in each attack.

As for the optimizers employed in the attacks, the L-BFGS liu1989limited and the Adam kingma2017adam are the most commonly used ones, see e.g., geiping2020inverting ; jeon2021gradient ; wang2020sapag ; wei2020framework ; yin2021see ; zhao2020idlg ; zhu2019deep . In particular, the reconstruction performance of the above two optimizers was compared in geiping2020inverting ; wang2020sapag ; wei2020framework . It has been shown in wei2020framework that the L-BFGS requires fewer attack iterations to achieve high reconstruction quality compared to the Adam when attacking the LFW dataset huang2008labeled . On the other hand, in geiping2020inverting , the L-BFGS performs worse than the Adam for the CIFAR-10 dataset krizhevsky2009learning . Although there is no definitive analysis guiding the selection of cost functions and optimizers, it is evident that appropriate choices can enhance the effectiveness of attacks in specific scenarios.

Another important way to improve the reconstruction performance is to add auxiliary regularization terms to the loss function for the attack based on some prior knowledge of the data. In wei2020framework , a label regularizer was proposed to match the dummy samples and labels when both of them are optimized simultaneously. Moreover, some image prior information can be employed for image reconstruction attacks, such as the total variation regularization geiping2020inverting to reduce the noise in images, and the group registration regularization yin2021see to center the position of the main object in images. In yin2021see , a prior term is proposed by using the values of the mean and variance of a batch of samples in batch normalization layers. A generative model pre-trained on the raw data distribution was used in jeon2021gradient to improve the reconstruction. However, in most distributed learning systems, batch normalization information and raw data distribution are not necessarily shared, which makes these methods less practical.

Despite remarkable progress, limited attention has been paid to attacking the FedAvg with multiple-step model updates, where clients share accumulated local model parameters after training for multiple epochs, each executed over multiple mini-batches. In this regard, an approximate and weighted method, named AGIC, is proposed in xu2022agic . The AGIC method employs a weighted cosine similarity loss function by assigning linearly increasing weights to different convolutional and fully connected layers. This method assumes that a combined batch consisting of all the mini-batches used in the client’s local training process can approximate the received model update in a single local update step. However, such an approximation method works only for scenarios with small local learning rates. Moreover, the weights are chosen empirically rather than systematically.

To address the above issues, we propose a novel approximate and weighted data reconstruction attack method against FL systems utilizing FedAvg algorithms. First, we present an interpolation-based approximation method that generates intermediate model updates of clients’ local training processes. As a result, attacking against the FedAvg with multiple-step model updates becomes feasible. Then, we propose a layer-wise weighted loss function to enhance the reconstruction quality. Different weights are assigned to model updates in each layer based on the neural network structure. The selection of the weights is optimized using the Bayesian optimization method.

Overall, our main contributions are as follows:

  1. 1.

    To attack the FedAvg with multiple-step model updates, we propose an interpolation-based approximation method. The model update corresponding to each epoch is approximated by interpolating the received combined model updates. The proposed approximation method makes attacks against FedAvg scenarios feasible and effective, as demonstrated by numerical experiments.

  2. 2.

    To further improve the attack performance after approximation, we employ a layer-wise weighted loss function for the attack. Different weights are assigned to different layers, and these weights are determined by the Bayesian optimization frazier2018tutorial . Additionally, we enhance the weights of layers with relatively larger errors, improving the attack’s adaptability and performance.

  3. 3.

    Our method demonstrates environment generality by being compatible with various neural network architectures, such as Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) and Residual Neural Networks (ResNets). Furthermore, it is capable of reconstructing training data based on the model updates leaked at different stages of the training process.

The rest of the paper is organized as follows. In Section 2, we provide a comprehensive background on FL and data reconstruction attacks. In Section 3, various attack scenarios are analyzed to identify the most challenging one. Section 4 presents our proposed method, including the approximation method and the layer-wise weighted loss function. The experimental setup and simulation results are presented in Section 5. Finally, we conclude the paper in Section 6.

2 Preliminaries

In this section, we first provide a detailed description of the mathematical formulation and training process of FL. Then, we introduce the formulation and setup of data reconstruction attacks.

2.1 Problem Statement of FL

FL aims to learn a machine learning model h:ℝdx×ℝdθ→ℝdy:ℎ→superscriptℝsubscript𝑑𝑥superscriptℝsubscript𝑑𝜃superscriptℝsubscript𝑑𝑦h:\mathbb{R}^{d_{x}}\times\mathbb{R}^{d_{\theta}}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{d_{y}}parameterized by θ∈ℝdθ𝜃superscriptℝsubscript𝑑𝜃\theta\in\mathbb{R}^{d_{\theta}} such that, given any data x∈ℝdx𝑥superscriptℝsubscript𝑑𝑥x\in\mathbb{R}^{d_{x}}, the value h​(x;θ)ℎ𝑥𝜃h(x;\theta) offers an accurate prediction about the label y∈ℝdy𝑦superscriptℝsubscript𝑑𝑦y\in\mathbb{R}^{d_{y}}. A crucial constraint in FL is that the training data and labels are stored across C𝐶C distributed clients, and each client’s data and labels can only be accessed and processed locally during the training process.

Mathematically, the training process of FL with C𝐶C clients can be formulated as the following minimization problem li2020federated :

2.2 FedAvg Algorithm

For solving (1), FL algorithms normally combine local model update processes performed by each client with model aggregation steps performed by a central server. To fix ideas, we focus on the FedAvg mcmahan2023communicationefficient , which is the most commonly used algorithm in FL. The FedAvg presented in Algorithm 1 involves a series of global rounds, in which the server first dispatches the latest global model parameters to a group of selected clients. Then, the selected clients compute model updates to the current global model with their private data and send the updated model parameters back to the server. Finally, the server aggregates the received model parameters to update the global model parameters, which serves as the initializer for the next round.

Next, we elaborate on the implementation of Algorithm 1. At each round t=1,2,…,T𝑡12…𝑇t=1,2,\ldots,T, the server selects a set of clients 𝒦⊆{k}k=1C𝒦superscriptsubscript𝑘𝑘1𝐶\mathcal{K}\subseteq\{k\}_{k=1}^{C} to participate the training and sends them the current global model parameters θtsubscript𝜃𝑡\theta_{t}. Then, each selected client k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K} sets its local model parameters θt(k)=θtsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑡𝑘subscript𝜃𝑡\theta_{t}^{(k)}=\theta_{t} and updates θt(k)superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑡𝑘\theta_{t}^{(k)} for E𝐸E epochs, each consisting of B(k)superscript𝐵𝑘B^{(k)} mini-batches.

In each epoch e=1,2,…,E𝑒12…𝐸e=1,2,\ldots,E, client k𝑘k first shuffles its dataset 𝒟(k)superscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}^{(k)} and partitions it into B(k)=N(k)/Msuperscript𝐵𝑘superscript𝑁𝑘𝑀B^{(k)}=N^{(k)}/M mini-batches (without loss of generality, we assume that the dataset is divisible into B(k)superscript𝐵𝑘B^{(k)} mini-batches of size M𝑀M):

𝒟(k)={(X(k),Y(k))}={(Xt,e,b(k),Yt,e,b(k))}b=1B(k),superscript𝒟𝑘superscript𝑋𝑘superscript𝑌𝑘superscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑋𝑡𝑒𝑏𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑌𝑡𝑒𝑏𝑘𝑏1superscript𝐵𝑘\mathcal{D}^{(k)}=\{(X^{(k)},Y^{(k)})\}=\{(X_{t,e,b}^{(k)},Y_{t,e,b}^{(k)})\}_{b=1}^{B^{(k)}}, (2)

where X(k)={xi(k)}i=1N(k)superscript𝑋𝑘superscriptsubscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑘𝑖𝑖1superscript𝑁𝑘X^{(k)}=\{x^{(k)}_{i}\}_{i=1}^{N^{(k)}} is the set of the training data, Y(k)={yi(k)}i=1N(k)superscript𝑌𝑘superscriptsubscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑦𝑘𝑖𝑖1superscript𝑁𝑘Y^{(k)}=\{y^{(k)}_{i}\}_{i=1}^{N^{(k)}} is the set of the labels, and {(Xt,e,b(k),Yt,e,b(k))}superscriptsubscript𝑋𝑡𝑒𝑏𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑌𝑡𝑒𝑏𝑘\{(X_{t,e,b}^{(k)},Y_{t,e,b}^{(k)})\} represents the training set for the b𝑏b-th mini-batch at round t𝑡t, epoch e𝑒e. If not otherwise stated, the subscripts t𝑡t, e𝑒e, and b𝑏b in the following discussions indicate the index of the round, the epoch, and the mini-batch, respectively.

For each mini-batch b=1,2,…,B(k)𝑏12…superscript𝐵𝑘b=1,2,\ldots,B^{(k)}, client k𝑘k updates its local model parameters θt,e,b(k):=θt(k)assignsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑡𝑒𝑏𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑡𝑘\theta_{t,e,b}^{(k)}:=\theta_{t}^{(k)} using the mini-batch gradient descent:

(4)

Then, client k𝑘k sends its updated local model parameter θt+1(k)superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑡1𝑘\theta_{t+1}^{(k)} back to the server for averaging.

After receiving updated local model parameters {θt+1(k)}k∈𝒦subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑡1𝑘𝑘𝒦\{\theta_{t+1}^{(k)}\}_{k\in\mathcal{K}} from the clients, the server performs the weighted model parameters averaging as follows:

2.3 Data Reconstruction Attack

Despite the fact that the clients only share the updated model parameters with the server, their private training data are still vulnerable to data reconstruction attacks geiping2020inverting ; yin2021see ; zhu2019deep . In this subsection, we introduce the formulation and the general procedure of a data reconstruction attack.

As shown in (4), during the local training process at round t𝑡t, client k𝑘k’s model parameters update Δ​θt(k)Δsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑡𝑘\Delta\theta_{t}^{(k)} consists of the averaged gradients computed on E×B(k)𝐸superscript𝐵𝑘E\times B^{(k)} mini-batches. Let Gt(k)superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑡𝑘G_{t}^{(k)} be a mapping from the training data {(X(k),Y(k))}superscript𝑋𝑘superscript𝑌𝑘\{(X^{(k)},Y^{(k)})\} defined in (2) to the model parameters update Δ​θt(k)Δsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑡𝑘\Delta\theta_{t}^{(k)}, then we can rewrite (4) in a compact manner as

Δ​θt(k)=Gt(k)​(X(k),Y(k)).Δsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑡𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑡𝑘superscript𝑋𝑘superscript𝑌𝑘\Delta\theta_{t}^{(k)}=G_{t}^{(k)}\left(X^{(k)},Y^{(k)}\right). (7)

For an attacker with access to Δ​θt(k)Δsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑡𝑘\Delta\theta_{t}^{(k)}, reconstructing {(X(k),Y(k))}superscript𝑋𝑘superscript𝑌𝑘\{(X^{(k)},Y^{(k)})\} is essentially an inverse problem. In particular, if [Gt(k)]−1superscriptdelimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑡𝑘1[G_{t}^{(k)}]^{-1} exists and is known analytically, the attacker can recover {(X(k),Y(k))}superscript𝑋𝑘superscript𝑌𝑘\{(X^{(k)},Y^{(k)})\} directly as follows:

(X(k),Y(k))=[Gt(k)]−1​(Δ​θt(k)).superscript𝑋𝑘superscript𝑌𝑘superscriptdelimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑡𝑘1Δsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑡𝑘\left(X^{(k)},Y^{(k)}\right)=[G_{t}^{(k)}]^{-1}\left(\Delta\theta_{t}^{(k)}\right). (8)

Notice that the attacker can independently attack any client k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K} that participated in the training at round t𝑡t.

However, since neural networks are highly nonlinear and the model updates are aggregated over multiple mini-batches, it is generally difficult to identify [Gt(k)]−1superscriptdelimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑡𝑘1[G_{t}^{(k)}]^{-1}. To address this issue, we introduce a numerical approach for solving (7). In the sequel we omit the superscript k𝑘k to simplify the notation.

Assuming an attacker can get access to the client’s training process and hence knows Gtsubscript𝐺𝑡G_{t}, then problem (7) can be solved by the numerical approach elaborated below. First, to launch the attack, the attacker randomly initializes a dummy dataset (X^,Y^)^𝑋^𝑌(\hat{X},\hat{Y}) with the same dimension as that of the client’s original dataset (X,Y)𝑋𝑌(X,Y). The attacker uses Gtsubscript𝐺𝑡G_{t} to calculate the dummy model update Δ​θ^tΔsubscript^𝜃𝑡\Delta\hat{\theta}_{t} given by

Δ​θ^t=Gt​(X^,Y^).Δsubscript^𝜃𝑡subscript𝐺𝑡^𝑋^𝑌\Delta\hat{\theta}_{t}=G_{t}(\hat{X},\hat{Y}). (9)

Proceeding as in zhu2019deep , the attacker can reconstruct the client’s dataset by matching the dummy model update Δ​θ^tΔsubscript^𝜃𝑡\Delta\hat{\theta}_{t} with the ground-truth model update Δ​θtΔsubscript𝜃𝑡\Delta\theta_{t}, minimizing a model update matching loss function ℓmsubscriptℓ𝑚\ell_{m} given by

ℓm​(X^,Y^)=‖Δ​θ^t−Δ​θt‖2=‖Gt​(X^,Y^)−Gt​(X,Y)‖2.subscriptℓ𝑚^𝑋^𝑌superscriptnormΔsubscript^𝜃𝑡Δsubscript𝜃𝑡2superscriptnormsubscript𝐺𝑡^𝑋^𝑌subscript𝐺𝑡𝑋𝑌2\ell_{m}(\hat{X},\hat{Y})=\|\Delta\hat{\theta}_{t}-\Delta\theta_{t}\|^{2}=\left\|G_{t}(\hat{X},\hat{Y})-G_{t}(X,Y)\right\|^{2}. (10)

In practice, one can also use other loss functions like the cosine similarity loss geiping2020inverting to evaluate the distance between Δ​θ^tΔsubscript^𝜃𝑡\Delta\hat{\theta}_{t} and Δ​θtΔsubscript𝜃𝑡\Delta\theta_{t}.

Therefore, the data reconstruction attack can be conducted by solving the following optimization problem:

(X^∗,Y^∗)=arg⁡minX^,Y^⁡ℓm​(X^,Y^).superscript^𝑋superscript^𝑌subscript^𝑋^𝑌subscriptℓ𝑚^𝑋^𝑌(\hat{X}^{*},\hat{Y}^{*})=\arg\min_{\hat{X},\hat{Y}}\ell_{m}(\hat{X},\hat{Y}). (11)

This can be done using the gradient descent method with the learning rate η^^𝜂\hat{\eta}:

X^←X^−η^​∇X^ℓm​(X^,Y^),Y^←Y^−η^​∇Y^ℓm​(X^,Y^).formulae-sequence←^𝑋^𝑋^𝜂subscript∇^𝑋subscriptℓ𝑚^𝑋^𝑌←^𝑌^𝑌^𝜂subscript∇^𝑌subscriptℓ𝑚^𝑋^𝑌\hat{X}\leftarrow\hat{X}-\hat{\eta}\nabla_{\hat{X}}\ell_{m}(\hat{X},\hat{Y}),\quad\hat{Y}\leftarrow\hat{Y}-\hat{\eta}\nabla_{\hat{Y}}\ell_{m}(\hat{X},\hat{Y}).
Remark 2.1.

In FL, the central server holds a substantial amount of information about the training process. Data reconstruction attacks can typically be developed by a honest-but-curious server geiping2020inverting , acting as attacker, who has access to the following information, and in particular Gtsubscript𝐺𝑡G_{t} in (9).

  1. 1.

    Model architecture of hhh: Normally the server decides the architecture of the neural network that is shared among all the clients.

  2. 2.

    Initial model parameters θtsubscriptθt\theta_{t}: For each client, its initial local model parameter θtsubscript𝜃𝑡\theta_{t} is dispatched from the server.

  3. 3.

    Model parameters update Δ​θtΔsubscriptθt\Delta\theta_{t}: Each client sends the updated model parameters θt+1subscript𝜃𝑡1\theta_{t+1} obtained in (5) back to the server. Thus, Δ​θt=θt+1−θtΔsubscript𝜃𝑡subscript𝜃𝑡1subscript𝜃𝑡\Delta\theta_{t}=\theta_{t+1}-\theta_{t} can be obtained by the server easily.

  4. 4.

    Loss function ℓℓ\ell: Similar to hℎh, it is common that the server decides the form of the loss function that is shared among all the clients. The choice made is kept unchanged during the training process.

  5. 5.

    Dataset size NNN: This information is shared with the server for weighted aggregation as shown in (6).

  6. 6.

    Client’s local training hyperparameters: As shown in (4) and (7), the knowledge of Gtsubscript𝐺𝑡G_{t} depends on the hyperparameters listed below. In general cases, the server can assign these hyperparameters to each client.

    1. (a)

      Number of epochs E𝐸E

    2. (b)

      Number of mini-batches B𝐵B

    3. (c)

      Learning rate η𝜂\eta

3 Analysis of Attack Scenarios: Different E𝐸E and B𝐵B

As shown in (9), a data reconstruction attack requires the knowledge of Gtsubscript𝐺𝑡G_{t} to calculate the dummy model update Δ​θ^tΔsubscript^𝜃𝑡\Delta\hat{\theta}_{t}. In this section, we discuss the difficulty of knowing Gtsubscript𝐺𝑡G_{t} for four FedAvg scenarios in terms of different values of E𝐸E and B𝐵B and, in particular, when E>1𝐸1E>1 and B>1𝐵1B>1.

Scenario 1: E=1,B=1formulae-sequence𝐸1𝐵1E=1,B=1.

As we shall see, the attacker can get access to Gtsubscript𝐺𝑡G_{t} and replicate the client’s training process. Indeed, since E=1𝐸1E=1 and B=1𝐵1B=1, the client uses the whole dataset for one epoch as follows:

Gt​(X,Y)=−η​∇θtℓ​(X,Y)=−η​1N​∑i=1N∇θtℓ​(xi,yi).subscript𝐺𝑡𝑋𝑌𝜂subscript∇subscript𝜃𝑡ℓ𝑋𝑌𝜂1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript∇subscript𝜃𝑡ℓsubscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖G_{t}(X,Y)=-\eta\nabla_{\theta_{t}}\ell\left(X,Y\right)=-\eta\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\nabla_{\theta_{t}}\ell\left(x_{i},y_{i}\right). (12)

Thus, the attacker can replicate the client’s training process by replacing (X,Y)𝑋𝑌(X,Y) with the dummy dataset (X^,Y^)={(x^i,y^i)}i=1N^𝑋^𝑌superscriptsubscriptsubscript^𝑥𝑖subscript^𝑦𝑖𝑖1𝑁(\hat{X},\hat{Y})=\{(\hat{x}_{i},\hat{y}_{i})\}_{i=1}^{N} in the following way:

Gt​(X^,Y^)=−η​∇θtℓ​(X^,Y^)=−η​1N​∑i=1N∇θtℓ​(x^i,y^i).subscript𝐺𝑡^𝑋^𝑌𝜂subscript∇subscript𝜃𝑡ℓ^𝑋^𝑌𝜂1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript∇subscript𝜃𝑡ℓsubscript^𝑥𝑖subscript^𝑦𝑖G_{t}(\hat{X},\hat{Y})=-\eta\nabla_{\theta_{t}}\ell\left(\hat{X},\hat{Y}\right)=-\eta\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\nabla_{\theta_{t}}\ell\left(\hat{x}_{i},\hat{y}_{i}\right). (13)
Scenario 2: E>1,B=1formulae-sequence𝐸1𝐵1E>1,B=1.

The attacker can also obtain the knowledge of Gtsubscript𝐺𝑡G_{t} in this scenario. To be concrete, the client uses the batch gradient descent for E𝐸E epochs:

Gt​(X,Y)=−η​∑e=1E∇θt,eℓ​(X,Y).subscript𝐺𝑡𝑋𝑌𝜂superscriptsubscript𝑒1𝐸subscript∇subscript𝜃𝑡𝑒ℓ𝑋𝑌G_{t}(X,Y)=-\eta\sum_{e=1}^{E}\nabla_{\theta_{t,e}}\ell\left(X,Y\right). (14)

In each epoch, since B=1𝐵1B=1, the gradients are computed on the N𝑁N samples, as in Scenario 1. In this case, the attacker can replicate the client’s training process by replacing (X,Y)𝑋𝑌(X,Y) with the dummy dataset (X^,Y^)^𝑋^𝑌(\hat{X},\hat{Y}), and train the model for E𝐸E epochs as follows:

Gt​(X^,Y^)=−η​∑e=1E∇θt,eℓ​(X^,Y^).subscript𝐺𝑡^𝑋^𝑌𝜂superscriptsubscript𝑒1𝐸subscript∇subscript𝜃𝑡𝑒ℓ^𝑋^𝑌G_{t}(\hat{X},\hat{Y})=-\eta\sum_{e=1}^{E}\nabla_{\theta_{t,e}}\ell\left(\hat{X},\hat{Y}\right). (15)
Scenario 3: E=1,B>1formulae-sequence𝐸1𝐵1E=1,B>1.

In this scenario, since B>1𝐵1B>1, the client uses the mini-batch gradient descent for one epoch in the following way:

Gt​(X,Y)=−η​∑b=1B∇θt,bℓ​(Xt,b,Yt,b)subscript𝐺𝑡𝑋𝑌𝜂superscriptsubscript𝑏1𝐵subscript∇subscript𝜃𝑡𝑏ℓsubscript𝑋𝑡𝑏subscript𝑌𝑡𝑏G_{t}(X,Y)=-\eta\sum_{b=1}^{B}\nabla_{\theta_{t,b}}\ell\left(X_{t,b},Y_{t,b}\right) (16)

with the gradients computed on B𝐵B mini-batches. At each epoch of the mini-batch gradient descent method, the client randomly shuffled the dataset and separates it into B𝐵B mini-batches. In this scenario, since E=1𝐸1E=1, the dataset is only shuffled once.

The attacker can first separate its dummy dataset (X^,Y^)^𝑋^𝑌(\hat{X},\hat{Y}) into B𝐵B mini-batches {(X^t,b,Y^t,b)}b=1Bsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript^𝑋𝑡𝑏subscript^𝑌𝑡𝑏𝑏1𝐵\{(\hat{X}_{t,b},\hat{Y}_{t,b})\}_{b=1}^{B}. Then, by replacing (Xt,b,Yt,b)subscript𝑋𝑡𝑏subscript𝑌𝑡𝑏(X_{t,b},Y_{t,b}) in (16) with (X^t,b,Y^t,b)subscript^𝑋𝑡𝑏subscript^𝑌𝑡𝑏(\hat{X}_{t,b},\hat{Y}_{t,b}), it can replicate the client’s training process as below:

Gt​(X^,Y^)=−η​∑b=1B∇θt,bℓ​(X^t,b,Y^t,b).subscript𝐺𝑡^𝑋^𝑌𝜂superscriptsubscript𝑏1𝐵subscript∇subscript𝜃𝑡𝑏ℓsubscript^𝑋𝑡𝑏subscript^𝑌𝑡𝑏G_{t}(\hat{X},\hat{Y})=-\eta\sum_{b=1}^{B}\nabla_{\theta_{t,b}}\ell\left(\hat{X}_{t,b},\hat{Y}_{t,b}\right). (17)

The only difference is that the reconstructed (X^,Y^)^𝑋^𝑌(\hat{X},\hat{Y}) are in the same order as that of the shuffled client’s dataset. Hence, the attacker can still obtain Gtsubscript𝐺𝑡G_{t} and replicate the local training process in this scenario.

Scenario 4: E>1,B>1formulae-sequence𝐸1𝐵1E>1,B>1.

In this case, the attacker cannot gain the needed knowledge of Gtsubscript𝐺𝑡G_{t} to calculate the dummy model update Δ​θ^tΔsubscript^𝜃𝑡\Delta\hat{\theta}_{t} defined in (9).

Indeed, the client uses the mini-batch gradient descent for E𝐸E epochs:

Gt​(X,Y)=−η​∑e=1E∑b=1B∇θt,e,bℓ​(Xt,e,b,Yt,e,b).subscript𝐺𝑡𝑋𝑌𝜂superscriptsubscript𝑒1𝐸superscriptsubscript𝑏1𝐵subscript∇subscript𝜃𝑡𝑒𝑏ℓsubscript𝑋𝑡𝑒𝑏subscript𝑌𝑡𝑒𝑏G_{t}(X,Y)=-\eta\sum_{e=1}^{E}\sum_{b=1}^{B}\nabla_{\theta_{t,e,b}}\ell\left(X_{t,e,b},Y_{t,e,b}\right). (18)

In each epoch, the client first shuffles its dataset and then separates it into B𝐵B mini-batches. As a result, the attacker cannot replicate the client’s mini-batch separation when E>1𝐸1E>1 due to the randomness of the shuffling process.

Most existing attack methods in the literature are only applicable to Scenarios 1-3 and limited attention has been given to the more challenging Scenario 4. To address it, we propose an interpolation-based approximation method. By interpolating the received model updates, we can approximate the model update corresponding to each epoch, thereby reducing the problem from Scenario 4 to Scenario 3. The details of the proposed method are presented in Section 4.1.

4 Approximate and Weighted Data Reconstruction Method

In this section, we propose an approximate and weighted data reconstruction attack method for solving (7).

4.1 Approximation of the intermediate model update {Δ​θt,e}e=1EsuperscriptsubscriptΔsubscript𝜃𝑡𝑒𝑒1𝐸\{\Delta\theta_{t,e}\}_{e=1}^{E} when E>1𝐸1E>1 and B>1𝐵1B>1

As discussed in Section 3, the shuffling of the dataset in each epoch makes it difficult for the attacker to know Gtsubscript𝐺𝑡G_{t}. However, if we know the intermediate model update Δ​θt,e,e∈{1,2,…,E}Δsubscript𝜃𝑡𝑒𝑒12…𝐸\Delta\theta_{t,e},e\in\{1,2,\ldots,E\} of each epoch, the problem can be reduced from Scenario 4 (E>1𝐸1E>1 and B>1𝐵1B>1) to Scenario 3 (E=1𝐸1E=1 and B>1𝐵1B>1) by attacking each epoch separately.

To this end, we interpolate between θt+1subscript𝜃𝑡1\theta_{t+1} and θtsubscript𝜃𝑡\theta_{t} to approximate the intermediate model parameters {θt,e}e=1Esuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝜃𝑡𝑒𝑒1𝐸\{\theta_{t,e}\}_{e=1}^{E} corresponding to each epoch. Particularly, consider a client who trains its model for E𝐸E epochs, the approximate intermediate model parameters {θ~t,e}e=1Esuperscriptsubscriptsubscript~𝜃𝑡𝑒𝑒1𝐸\{\tilde{\theta}_{t,e}\}_{e=1}^{E} can be obtained as

θ~t,e=θt+1−θtE​e+θtfor ​e=1,2,…,E.formulae-sequencesubscript~𝜃𝑡𝑒subscript𝜃𝑡1subscript𝜃𝑡𝐸𝑒subscript𝜃𝑡for 𝑒12…𝐸\tilde{\theta}_{t,e}=\frac{\theta_{t+1}-\theta_{t}}{E}e+\theta_{t}\quad\textnormal{for }e=1,2,\ldots,E. (19)

Then, the approximate model updates {Δ​θ~t,e}e=1EsuperscriptsubscriptΔsubscript~𝜃𝑡𝑒𝑒1𝐸\{\Delta\tilde{\theta}_{t,e}\}_{e=1}^{E} corresponding to each epoch can be obtained as

Δ​θ~t,e=θ~t,e−θ~t,e−1for ​e=1,2,…,E,formulae-sequenceΔsubscript~𝜃𝑡𝑒subscript~𝜃𝑡𝑒subscript~𝜃𝑡𝑒1for 𝑒12…𝐸\Delta\tilde{\theta}_{t,e}=\tilde{\theta}_{t,e}-\tilde{\theta}_{t,e-1}\quad\textnormal{for }e=1,2,\ldots,E, (20)

where θ~t,0=θtsubscript~𝜃𝑡0subscript𝜃𝑡\tilde{\theta}_{t,0}=\theta_{t} is the initial model parameter at round t𝑡t.

After obtaining the approximate {Δ​θ~t,e}e=1EsuperscriptsubscriptΔsubscript~𝜃𝑡𝑒𝑒1𝐸\{\Delta\tilde{\theta}_{t,e}\}_{e=1}^{E}, one can use it as the target model update of the corresponding epoch e∈{1,2,…,E}𝑒12…𝐸e\in\{1,2,\ldots,E\}. In other words, the problem is reduced from Scenario 4 (E>1𝐸1E>1 and B>1𝐵1B>1) to Scenario 3 (E=1𝐸1E=1 and B>1𝐵1B>1).

Let Gt,esubscript𝐺𝑡𝑒G_{t,e} denote the client’s training process of epoch e𝑒e at round t𝑡t. Then, the dummy model update Δ​θ^t,eΔsubscript^𝜃𝑡𝑒\Delta\hat{\theta}_{t,e} can be obtained based on (17), given as

Δ​θ^t,e=Gt,e​(X^,Y^)=−η​∑b=1B∇θt,e,bℓ​(X^t,e,b,Y^t,e,b).Δsubscript^𝜃𝑡𝑒subscript𝐺𝑡𝑒^𝑋^𝑌𝜂superscriptsubscript𝑏1𝐵subscript∇subscript𝜃𝑡𝑒𝑏ℓsubscript^𝑋𝑡𝑒𝑏subscript^𝑌𝑡𝑒𝑏\Delta\hat{\theta}_{t,e}=G_{t,e}(\hat{X},\hat{Y})=-\eta\sum_{b=1}^{B}\nabla_{\theta_{t,e,b}}\ell\left(\hat{X}_{t,e,b},\hat{Y}_{t,e,b}\right). (21)

Finally, the attack can be conducted following the procedures of Scenario 3.

4.2 Improved Weighted Loss Function for the Data Reconstruction Attack

The standard loss function (10) for the data reconstruction attack treats different components of the model update Δ​θtΔsubscript𝜃𝑡\Delta\theta_{t} equally. However, as observed in chen2019shallowing , different layers in a neural network provide different contributions to boosting the performance. Inspired by this fact, we propose to assign different weights to the model updates in different layers to facilitate the reconstruction. The implementation of our method is elaborated in this section.

Consider a neural network with L𝐿L layers. Then the model update Δ​θtΔsubscript𝜃𝑡\Delta\theta_{t} consists of superposition of the updates Δ​θt(l)Δsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑡𝑙\Delta\theta_{t}^{(l)} of each layer:

Δ​θt={Δ​θt(l)}l=1L.Δsubscript𝜃𝑡superscriptsubscriptΔsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑡𝑙𝑙1𝐿\Delta\theta_{t}=\{\Delta\theta_{t}^{(l)}\}_{l=1}^{L}. (22)

The same applies to the dummy model updates Δ​θt^={Δ​θ^t(l)}l=1LΔ^subscript𝜃𝑡superscriptsubscriptΔsuperscriptsubscript^𝜃𝑡𝑙𝑙1𝐿\Delta\hat{\theta_{t}}=\{\Delta\hat{\theta}_{t}^{(l)}\}_{l=1}^{L}.

By assigning the weight q(l)>0superscript𝑞𝑙0q^{(l)}>0 to the model updates at layer l𝑙l, the loss function (10) for the attack becomes

ℓQ​(X^,Y^)=∑l=1Lq(l)​‖Δ​θ^t(l)−Δ​θt(l)‖2.subscriptℓ𝑄^𝑋^𝑌superscriptsubscript𝑙1𝐿superscript𝑞𝑙superscriptnormΔsuperscriptsubscript^𝜃𝑡𝑙Δsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑡𝑙2\ell_{Q}(\hat{X},\hat{Y})=\sum_{l=1}^{L}q^{(l)}\left\|\Delta\hat{\theta}_{t}^{(l)}-\Delta\theta_{t}^{(l)}\right\|^{2}. (23)

Then, the crucial question is how to choose layer weights q(l)superscript𝑞𝑙q^{(l)} to improve the reconstruction.

4.2.1 Design of Layer Weights

Increasing weights layer by layer.

We consider linearly increasing weight functions for difference types of layers.

To expose our ideas clearly, we focus on the commonly used ResNet architecture he2016deep , which contains convolutional, batch normalization, and fully connected layers.

We design the following weight functions for each kind of layer:

qc​v(l)={qc​v−1Lc​v−1​(l−1)+1,if ​l=1,2,…,Lc​v>1,qc​v,if ​l=Lc​v=1,superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑐𝑣𝑙casessubscript𝑞𝑐𝑣1subscript𝐿𝑐𝑣1𝑙11formulae-sequenceif 𝑙12…subscript𝐿𝑐𝑣1subscript𝑞𝑐𝑣if 𝑙subscript𝐿𝑐𝑣1\displaystyle\begin{split}q_{cv}^{(l)}&=\begin{cases}\frac{q_{cv}-1}{L_{cv}-1}(l-1)+1,&\text{if }l=1,2,...,L_{cv}>1,\\ q_{cv},&\text{if }l=L_{cv}=1,\end{cases}\end{split} (24a)
qb​n(l)={qb​n−1Lb​n−1​(l−1)+1,if ​l=1,2,…,Lb​n>1,qb​n,if ​l=Lb​n=1,superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑏𝑛𝑙casessubscript𝑞𝑏𝑛1subscript𝐿𝑏𝑛1𝑙11formulae-sequenceif 𝑙12…subscript𝐿𝑏𝑛1subscript𝑞𝑏𝑛if 𝑙subscript𝐿𝑏𝑛1\displaystyle\begin{split}q_{bn}^{(l)}&=\begin{cases}\frac{q_{bn}-1}{L_{bn}-1}(l-1)+1,&\text{if }l=1,2,...,L_{bn}>1,\\ q_{bn},&\text{if }l=L_{bn}=1,\end{cases}\end{split} (24b)
qf​c(l)={qf​c−1Lf​c−1​(l−1)+1,if ​l=1,2,…,Lf​c>1,qf​c,if ​l=Lf​c=1,superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑓𝑐𝑙casessubscript𝑞𝑓𝑐1subscript𝐿𝑓𝑐1𝑙11formulae-sequenceif 𝑙12…subscript𝐿𝑓𝑐1subscript𝑞𝑓𝑐if 𝑙subscript𝐿𝑓𝑐1\displaystyle\begin{split}q_{fc}^{(l)}&=\begin{cases}\frac{q_{fc}-1}{L_{fc}-1}(l-1)+1,&\text{if }l=1,2,...,L_{fc}>1,\\ q_{fc},&\text{if }l=L_{fc}=1,\end{cases}\end{split} (24c)

where Lc​vsubscript𝐿𝑐𝑣L_{cv}, Lb​nsubscript𝐿𝑏𝑛L_{bn}, and Lf​csubscript𝐿𝑓𝑐L_{fc} are the numbers of the convolutional, batch normalization, and fully connected layers, respectively, and L=Lc​v+Lb​n+Lf​c𝐿subscript𝐿𝑐𝑣subscript𝐿𝑏𝑛subscript𝐿𝑓𝑐L=L_{cv}+L_{bn}+L_{fc}. The values of qc​v>1subscript𝑞𝑐𝑣1q_{cv}>1, qb​n>1subscript𝑞𝑏𝑛1q_{bn}>1 and qf​c>1subscript𝑞𝑓𝑐1q_{fc}>1 are the largest weights assigned to the last layer. For a given neural network with a fixed number of layers (Lc​vsubscript𝐿𝑐𝑣L_{cv}, Lb​nsubscript𝐿𝑏𝑛L_{bn} and Lf​csubscript𝐿𝑓𝑐L_{fc}), the values of qc​vsubscript𝑞𝑐𝑣q_{cv}, qb​nsubscript𝑞𝑏𝑛q_{bn} and qf​csubscript𝑞𝑓𝑐q_{fc} determine the slope of the linearly increasing weight functions in (24).

Enhancing the weights of layers with larger errors.

Adding linearly increasing weights determined by (24) to the loss function (23) may overly emphasize the importance of some layers in the neural network and lead to a biased reconstruction. To strike a balance between adding linearly increasing weights and avoiding biased reconstructions, we propose to modify the weights of layers with larger errors by exploiting the statistical information like the mean μ​(⋅)𝜇⋅\mu(\cdot) and the variance σ2​(⋅)superscript𝜎2⋅\sigma^{2}(\cdot) of the layer-wise model updates {Δ​θt(l)}l=1LsuperscriptsubscriptΔsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑡𝑙𝑙1𝐿\{\Delta\theta_{t}^{(l)}\}_{l=1}^{L} in (22). The procedure of our enhancing method is elaborated below.

First, we calculate the relative error em​e​a​n(l)superscriptsubscript𝑒𝑚𝑒𝑎𝑛𝑙e_{mean}^{(l)} and ev​a​r(l)superscriptsubscript𝑒𝑣𝑎𝑟𝑙e_{var}^{(l)} of the dummy model update Δ​θ^t(l)Δsuperscriptsubscript^𝜃𝑡𝑙\Delta\hat{\theta}_{t}^{(l)} and the real model update Δ​θt(l)Δsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑡𝑙\Delta\theta_{t}^{(l)} at each layer l=1,2,…,L𝑙12…𝐿l=1,2,...,L as follows:

em​e​a​n(l)=|μ​(Δ​θ^t(l))−μ​(Δ​θt(l))||μ​(Δ​θt(l))|,l=1,2,…,L,formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑒𝑚𝑒𝑎𝑛𝑙𝜇Δsuperscriptsubscript^𝜃𝑡𝑙𝜇Δsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑡𝑙𝜇Δsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑡𝑙𝑙12…𝐿e_{mean}^{(l)}=\frac{|\mu(\Delta\hat{\theta}_{t}^{(l)})-\mu(\Delta\theta_{t}^{(l)})|}{|\mu(\Delta\theta_{t}^{(l)})|},\quad l=1,2,...,L, (25)
ev​a​r(l)=|σ2​(Δ​θ^t(l))−σ2​(Δ​θt(l))||σ2​(Δ​θt(l))|,l=1,2,…,L.formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑒𝑣𝑎𝑟𝑙superscript𝜎2Δsuperscriptsubscript^𝜃𝑡𝑙superscript𝜎2Δsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑡𝑙superscript𝜎2Δsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑡𝑙𝑙12…𝐿e_{var}^{(l)}=\frac{|\sigma^{2}(\Delta\hat{\theta}_{t}^{(l)})-\sigma^{2}(\Delta\theta_{t}^{(l)})|}{|\sigma^{2}(\Delta\theta_{t}^{(l)})|},\quad l=1,2,...,L. (26)

Next, we select a subset 𝒫⊆ℒ={l}l=1L𝒫ℒsuperscriptsubscript𝑙𝑙1𝐿\mathcal{P}\subseteq\mathcal{L}=\{l\}_{l=1}^{L} of layers with the largest relative errors in terms of {em​e​a​n(l)}l=1Lsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑒𝑚𝑒𝑎𝑛𝑙𝑙1𝐿\{e_{mean}^{(l)}\}_{l=1}^{L} and {ev​a​r(l)}l=1Lsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑒𝑣𝑎𝑟𝑙𝑙1𝐿\{e_{var}^{(l)}\}_{l=1}^{L}, and set their layer weights q(l)superscript𝑞𝑙q^{(l)} to qe​n∈ℝsubscript𝑞𝑒𝑛ℝq_{en}\in\mathbb{R}, i.e.,

q(l)=qe​n,l∈𝒫.formulae-sequencesuperscript𝑞𝑙subscript𝑞𝑒𝑛𝑙𝒫q^{(l)}=q_{en},\quad l\in\mathcal{P}. (27)

The choice of the subset 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P} can be decided by the proportional parameters pm​e​a​n∈[0,1]subscript𝑝𝑚𝑒𝑎𝑛01p_{mean}\in[0,1] and pv​a​r∈[0,1]subscript𝑝𝑣𝑎𝑟01p_{var}\in[0,1] in the following way: For a given pm​e​a​nsubscript𝑝𝑚𝑒𝑎𝑛p_{mean}, we first select Nm​e​a​n=⌈pm​e​a​n⋅L⌉subscript𝑁𝑚𝑒𝑎𝑛⋅subscript𝑝𝑚𝑒𝑎𝑛𝐿N_{mean}=\lceil p_{mean}\cdot L\rceil layers with the largest relative error in terms of {em​e​a​n(l)}l=1Lsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑒𝑚𝑒𝑎𝑛𝑙𝑙1𝐿\{e_{mean}^{(l)}\}_{l=1}^{L}. Similarly, we can get a set 𝒫v​a​rsubscript𝒫𝑣𝑎𝑟\mathcal{P}_{var} with Nv​a​r=⌈pv​a​r⋅L⌉subscript𝑁𝑣𝑎𝑟⋅subscript𝑝𝑣𝑎𝑟𝐿N_{var}=\lceil p_{var}\cdot L\rceil elements as

where j1,j2,…,jNv​a​r∈{1,2,…,L}subscript𝑗1subscript𝑗2…subscript𝑗subscript𝑁𝑣𝑎𝑟12…𝐿j_{1},j_{2},\ldots,j_{N_{var}}\in\{1,2,\ldots,L\} are the indices that satisfy ev​a​r(j1)≥ev​a​r(j2)≥…≥ev​a​r(jNv​a​r)≥ev​a​r(l),(l∈ℒ∖𝒫v​a​r)formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑒𝑣𝑎𝑟subscript𝑗1superscriptsubscript𝑒𝑣𝑎𝑟subscript𝑗2…superscriptsubscript𝑒𝑣𝑎𝑟subscript𝑗subscript𝑁𝑣𝑎𝑟superscriptsubscript𝑒𝑣𝑎𝑟𝑙𝑙ℒsubscript𝒫𝑣𝑎𝑟e_{var}^{(j_{1})}\geq e_{var}^{(j_{2})}\geq\ldots\geq e_{var}^{(j_{N_{var}})}\geq e_{var}^{(l)},(l\in\mathcal{L}\setminus\mathcal{P}_{var}).

Finally, the subset 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P} can be obtained as the intersection of 𝒫m​e​a​nsubscript𝒫𝑚𝑒𝑎𝑛\mathcal{P}_{mean} and 𝒫v​a​rsubscript𝒫𝑣𝑎𝑟\mathcal{P}_{var}:

𝒫=𝒫m​e​a​n∩𝒫v​a​r.𝒫subscript𝒫𝑚𝑒𝑎𝑛subscript𝒫𝑣𝑎𝑟\mathcal{P}=\mathcal{P}_{mean}\cap\mathcal{P}_{var}. (30)
Hyperparameters to tune.

Following (24) and (27), the layer weights {q(l)}l=1Lsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑞𝑙𝑙1𝐿\{q^{(l)}\}_{l=1}^{L} in (23) are determined by the parameter vector Q∈ℝ6𝑄superscriptℝ6Q\in\mathbb{R}^{6}, which is defined as

Q=(qc​v,qb​n,qf​c,qe​n,pm​e​a​n,pv​a​r).𝑄subscript𝑞𝑐𝑣subscript𝑞𝑏𝑛subscript𝑞𝑓𝑐subscript𝑞𝑒𝑛subscript𝑝𝑚𝑒𝑎𝑛subscript𝑝𝑣𝑎𝑟Q=(q_{cv},q_{bn},q_{fc},q_{en},p_{mean},p_{var}). (31)

Given Q𝑄Q, by using the weighted loss function (23), one can obtain the reconstructed data (X^∗,Y^∗)superscript^𝑋superscript^𝑌(\hat{X}^{*},\hat{Y}^{*}) by solving the following optimization problem:

(X^∗,Y^∗)=arg⁡minX^,Y^⁡ℓQ​(X^,Y^).superscript^𝑋superscript^𝑌subscript^𝑋^𝑌subscriptℓ𝑄^𝑋^𝑌(\hat{X}^{*},\hat{Y}^{*})=\arg\min_{\hat{X},\hat{Y}}\ell_{Q}(\hat{X},\hat{Y}). (32)

Then, the question becomes how to choose a proper Q𝑄Q for a better reconstruction.

4.2.2 Choice of Q𝑄Q by Bayesian Optimization

Objective function.

As shown in (32), one can obtain the reconstructed data (X^∗,Y^∗)superscript^𝑋superscript^𝑌(\hat{X}^{*},\hat{Y}^{*}) with a given Q𝑄Q. Then, the corresponding dummy model update Δ​θ^∗Δsuperscript^𝜃\Delta\hat{\theta}^{*} can be calculated as Δ​θ^∗=Gt​(X^∗,Y^∗)Δsuperscript^𝜃subscript𝐺𝑡superscript^𝑋superscript^𝑌\Delta\hat{\theta}^{*}=G_{t}(\hat{X}^{*},\hat{Y}^{*}).

Let f:ℝ6→ℝ:𝑓→superscriptℝ6ℝf:\mathbb{R}^{6}\rightarrow\mathbb{R} be the objective function in the form of l2subscript𝑙2l_{2} distance of the dummy model update Δ​θ^∗Δsuperscript^𝜃\Delta\hat{\theta}^{*} and the ground-truth model update Δ​θΔ𝜃\Delta\theta as follows:

f​(Q)=‖Δ​θ^t∗−Δ​θt‖2.𝑓𝑄superscriptnormΔsubscriptsuperscript^𝜃𝑡Δsubscript𝜃𝑡2f(Q)=\left\|\Delta\hat{\theta}^{*}_{t}-\Delta\theta_{t}\right\|^{2}. (33)

Finding the optimal Q∗superscript𝑄Q^{*} is equivalent to solving the following optimization problem:

Q∗=arg⁡minQ⁡f​(Q).superscript𝑄subscript𝑄𝑓𝑄Q^{*}=\arg\min_{Q}f(Q). (34)

For this optimization problem, f𝑓f is a black box function that does not have an analytic expression. Meanwhile, calculating f𝑓f is computationally expensive since one has to complete a reconstruction attack to obtain (X^∗,Y^∗)superscript^𝑋superscript^𝑌(\hat{X}^{*},\hat{Y}^{*}). Hence, traditional parameter determination methods like grid search are not feasible. To overcome the above difficulties, we employ the Bayesian optimization frazier2018tutorial to solve (34).

A Bayesian optimization algorithm for (34).

Bayesian optimization is a powerful technique for optimizing black-box functions that are expensive to evaluate and may have noise or other sources of uncertainty frazier2018tutorial . In general, Bayesian optimization iteratively uses a surrogate function to approximate the black-box function and then employs an acquisition function to determine the next set of parameters to evaluate.

The surrogate model works to approximate the black-box objective function f𝑓f, which is commonly chosen to be a Gaussian process (GP). Formally, a GP is a collection of random variables, any finite number of which have a joint Gaussian distribution rasmussen2006gaussian .

Given an initial set 𝒪={(𝑸,𝒇)}:={Qi,f​(Qi)}i=1n𝒪𝑸𝒇assignsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑄𝑖𝑓subscript𝑄𝑖𝑖1𝑛\mathcal{O}=\{(\bm{Q},\bm{f})\}:=\left\{Q_{i},f(Q_{i})\right\}_{i=1}^{n} that contains n𝑛n pairs of the sampling points and their function values, the resulting prior distribution over 𝒇𝒇\bm{f} can be given as

𝒇∼𝒩​(𝝁,𝚺),similar-to𝒇𝒩𝝁𝚺\bm{f}\sim\mathcal{N}(\bm{\mu},\bm{\Sigma}), (35)

where 𝝁=(μ​(Q1),…,μ​(Qn))𝝁𝜇subscript𝑄1…𝜇subscript𝑄𝑛\bm{\mu}=\left(\mu\left(Q_{1}\right),\ldots,\mu\left(Q_{n}\right)\right), μ𝜇\mu is the mean function and commonly set to zero, 𝚺=κ​(𝑸,𝑸)𝚺𝜅𝑸𝑸\bm{\Sigma}=\kappa\left(\bm{Q},\bm{Q}\right), and κ𝜅\kappa is a positive definite kernel function usually set to be the Gaussian kernel.

Then, we can infer the value of f​(Q)𝑓𝑄f(Q) at any point Q𝑄Q by computing the posterior distribution of f​(Q)𝑓𝑄f(Q) given prior observations using Bayes’ rule rasmussen2006gaussian :

f​(Q)∣𝒇conditional𝑓𝑄𝒇\displaystyle f(Q)\mid\bm{f} ∼𝒩​(μ​(Q),σ2​(Q)),similar-toabsent𝒩𝜇𝑄superscript𝜎2𝑄\displaystyle\sim\mathcal{N}(\mu(Q),\sigma^{2}(Q)), (36)
μ​(Q)𝜇𝑄\displaystyle\mu(Q) =κ​(Q,𝑸)​𝚺−1​𝒇,absent𝜅𝑄𝑸superscript𝚺1𝒇\displaystyle=\kappa(Q,\bm{Q})\bm{\Sigma}^{-1}\bm{f},
σ2​(Q)superscript𝜎2𝑄\displaystyle\sigma^{2}(Q) =κ​(Q,Q)−κ​(Q,𝑸)​𝚺−1​κ​(𝑸,Q).absent𝜅𝑄𝑄𝜅𝑄𝑸superscript𝚺1𝜅𝑸𝑄\displaystyle=\kappa(Q,Q)-\kappa(Q,\bm{Q})\bm{\Sigma}^{-1}\kappa(\bm{Q},Q).

The role of the acquisition function is to propose the parameters for the next trial by trading off exploitation and exploration. Exploitation means sampling where the surrogate model predicts a high objective and exploration means sampling at locations where the prediction uncertainty is high.

One of the most popular acquisition functions is Expected Improvement (EI) mockus1975bayesian . Let fminsubscript𝑓f_{\min} denote the best function value obtained so far. Then, the improvement over fminsubscript𝑓f_{\min} at point Q𝑄Q can be defined as

I​(Q)=max⁡(fmin−f​(Q),0).𝐼𝑄subscript𝑓𝑓𝑄0I(Q)=\max(f_{\min}-f(Q),0). (37)

The improvement I​(Q)𝐼𝑄I(Q) is a random variable since f​(Q)∼𝒩​(μ​(Q),σ2​(Q))similar-to𝑓𝑄𝒩𝜇𝑄superscript𝜎2𝑄f(Q)\sim\mathcal{N}\left(\mu(Q),\sigma^{2}(Q)\right) as shown in (36). To obtain the expected improvement we can take the expected value as follows:

EI​(Q)=𝔼​[max⁡(fmin−f​(Q),0)].EI𝑄𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑓𝑓𝑄0\mathrm{EI}(Q)=\mathbb{E}[\max(f_{\min}-f(Q),0)]. (38)

The expected improvement can be evaluated analytically under the GP jones1998efficient , given as:

EI​(Q)=(fmin−μ​(Q))​Φ​(fmin−μ​(Q)σ​(Q))+σ​(Q)​ϕ​(fmin−μ​(Q)σ​(Q)),EI𝑄subscript𝑓𝜇𝑄Φsubscript𝑓𝜇𝑄𝜎𝑄𝜎𝑄italic-ϕsubscript𝑓𝜇𝑄𝜎𝑄\mathrm{EI}(Q)=\left(f_{\min}-\mu(Q)\right)\Phi\left(\frac{f_{\min}-\mu(Q)}{\sigma(Q)}\right)+\sigma(Q)\phi\left(\frac{f_{\min}-\mu(Q)}{\sigma(Q)}\right), (39)

where ϕitalic-ϕ\phi and ΦΦ\Phi are the probability density and cumulative distribution functions of the standard normal distribution, respectively. It can be seen that the value of the function EIEI\mathrm{EI} is high for a point Q𝑄Q predicted to have a small μ​(Q)𝜇𝑄\mu(Q) and a large σ​(Q)𝜎𝑄\sigma(Q), indicating the trade-off between the exploitation and exploration.

Given the EIEI\mathrm{EI}, the parameter Q𝑄Q for the next trial is chosen to be the point with the largest expected improvement:

Q=arg⁡maxQ⁡EI​(Q).𝑄subscript𝑄EI𝑄Q=\arg\max_{Q}\mathrm{EI}(Q). (40)

The evaluation of EI​(Q)EI𝑄\mathrm{EI}(Q) is much easier than that of the function f𝑓f in (34). The optimization problem (40) can be solved by some classic optimization techniques such as Newton’s method.

4.3 Approximate and weighted data reconstruction attack method

Based on the discussions in Sections 4.1-4.2, we propose an approximate and weighted data reconstruction attack method and list it in Algorithm 2.

5 Experimental Tests

In this section, we report some numerical results to validate the effectiveness of our proposed AWA method given in Algorithm 2. We first introduce experimental environments and implementation details used in our experiments. We then explain the choice of hyperparameters and describe the evaluation metrics. After that, we test the AWA for image data reconstruction and compare the performance of AWA with two state-of-the-art attack algorithms (AGIC xu2022agic and DLG zhu2019deep ) in different FedAvg scenarios.

5.1 Setups

Hardware.

For all the experiments, we use a computer equipped with an Xeon E5-2680 v4 CPU, 32GB of RAM, and an NVIDIA GeForce RTX 1080 Ti GPU.

Implementation details.

To implement the FedAvg, some images from the dataset CIFAR-10 (size 32 × 32, 10 classes) krizhevsky2009learning are used as the clients’ training data. The model used by each client is the ResNet18 he2016deep , which contains 17 convolutional layers, 17 batch-normalization layers, and 1 fully connected layer. The client’s local training uses a stochastic gradient descent with a learning rate of 0.001. For the attack optimizations in (11), the Adam optimizer kingma2017adam with a learning rate of 0.1 is used and each attack runs for 1000 iterations. Following the label inference method in geng2023improved ; yin2021see , we proceed with the assumption that the label information is known. Table 1 lists the simulation scenarios of the data reconstruction attack.

In the AWA method, the parameter Q𝑄Q (31) is selected by the Bayesian optimization frazier2018tutorial , where we use the Gaussian process (36) as the surrogate model and the expected improvement (39) as the acquisition function. The objective function of the Bayesian optimization is the squared Euclidean distance of the dummy model update Δ​θ^∗Δsuperscript^𝜃\Delta\hat{\theta}^{*} and the ground-truth model update Δ​θΔ𝜃\Delta\theta as defined in (33). We run the Bayesian optimization for NB​O=50subscript𝑁𝐵𝑂50N_{BO}=50 iterations, with the first n=12𝑛12n=12 iterations initiating the dataset 𝒪𝒪\mathcal{O}. The search ranges of Q𝑄Q are listed in Table 2.

Evaluation metrics.

In order to evaluate the efficiency of the attach and the quality of the data reconstruction, we use three different metrics to measure the dissimilarity between reconstructed data and the real data: pixel-wise Mean Square Error (MSE), Peak Signal-to-Noise Ratio (PSNR) sara2019image , and Structural Similarity Index Measure (SSIM) wang2004imagea . The above three metrics are prevalent and appropriate indicators in evaluating the effect of image reconstruction sara2019image , and they have been widely used in evaluating the existing data reconstruction attacks, see geiping2020inverting ; wei2020framework ; yin2021see .

  • •

    MSE is the degree of variation between the original image 𝑫𝑫\bm{D} and the reconstruction image 𝑫′superscript𝑫bold-′\bm{D^{\prime}} and is defined by

    MSE⁡(𝑫,𝑫′)=1dm​dn​∑i=0dm−1∑j=0dn−1[𝑫​(i,j)−𝑫′​(i,j)]2,MSE𝑫superscript𝑫bold-′1subscript𝑑𝑚subscript𝑑𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖0subscript𝑑𝑚1superscriptsubscript𝑗0subscript𝑑𝑛1superscriptdelimited-[]𝑫𝑖𝑗superscript𝑫bold-′𝑖𝑗2\operatorname{MSE}(\bm{D},\bm{D^{\prime}})=\frac{1}{d_{m}d_{n}}\sum_{i=0}^{d_{m}-1}\sum_{j=0}^{d_{n}-1}[\bm{D}(i,j)-\bm{D^{\prime}}(i,j)]^{2},

    where dm×dnsubscript𝑑𝑚subscript𝑑𝑛d_{m}\times d_{n} is the dimension of images; 𝑫​(i,j)𝑫𝑖𝑗\bm{D}(i,j) and 𝑫′​(i,j)superscript𝑫bold-′𝑖𝑗\bm{D^{\prime}}(i,j) are the pixel values at coordinates (i,j)𝑖𝑗(i,j) of 𝑫𝑫\bm{D} and 𝑫′superscript𝑫bold-′\bm{D^{\prime}}. Clearly, a smaller value of MSE indicates a better reconstruction quality.

  • •

    PSNR represents the rate of the maximum possible signal power to the distortion noise power. PSNR is calculated as

    PSNR⁡(𝑫,𝑫′)=10​log10⁡Max𝑫2MSE⁡(𝑫,𝑫′),PSNR𝑫superscript𝑫bold-′10subscript10superscriptsubscriptMax𝑫2MSE𝑫superscript𝑫bold-′\operatorname{PSNR}(\bm{D},\bm{D^{\prime}})=10\log_{10}\frac{\operatorname{Max}_{\bm{D}}^{2}}{\operatorname{MSE}(\bm{D},\bm{D^{\prime}})},

    where Max𝑫subscriptMax𝑫\operatorname{Max}_{\bm{D}} is the maximum possible value of pixels in the original image 𝑫𝑫\bm{D}. It is easy to see that the larger the PSNR value, the better the image reconstruction quality.

  • •

    SSIM measures the structural similarity between the original and reconstructed images. The value of SSIM ranges between zero and one, with a higher value indicating a better reconstruction. To be concrete, SSIM is calculated as

    SSIM⁡(𝑫,𝑫′)=(2​μ𝑫​μ𝑫′+c1)​(2​σ𝑫​𝑫′+c2)(μ𝑫2+μ𝑫′2+c1)​(σ𝑫2+σ𝑫′2+c2).SSIM𝑫superscript𝑫bold-′2subscript𝜇𝑫subscript𝜇superscript𝑫bold-′subscript𝑐12subscript𝜎𝑫superscript𝑫bold-′subscript𝑐2superscriptsubscript𝜇𝑫2superscriptsubscript𝜇superscript𝑫bold-′2subscript𝑐1superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑫2superscriptsubscript𝜎superscript𝑫bold-′2subscript𝑐2\operatorname{SSIM}(\bm{D},\bm{D^{\prime}})=\frac{\left(2\mu_{\bm{D}}\mu_{\bm{D^{\prime}}}+c_{1}\right)\left(2\sigma_{\bm{D}\bm{D^{\prime}}}+c_{2}\right)}{\left(\mu_{\bm{D}}^{2}+\mu_{\bm{D^{\prime}}}^{2}+c_{1}\right)\left(\sigma_{\bm{D}}^{2}+\sigma_{\bm{D^{\prime}}}^{2}+c_{2}\right)}.

    Here, μ𝑫subscript𝜇𝑫\mu_{\bm{D}} and μ𝑫′subscript𝜇superscript𝑫bold-′\mu_{\bm{D^{\prime}}} are the average pixel values of 𝑫𝑫\bm{D} and 𝑫′superscript𝑫bold-′\bm{D^{\prime}}, σ𝑫subscript𝜎𝑫\sigma_{\bm{D}} and σ𝑫′subscript𝜎superscript𝑫bold-′\sigma_{\bm{D^{\prime}}} are the standard deviations of pixel values of 𝑫𝑫\bm{D} and 𝑫′superscript𝑫bold-′\bm{D^{\prime}}, σ𝑫​𝑫′subscript𝜎𝑫superscript𝑫bold-′\sigma_{\bm{D}\bm{D^{\prime}}} is the covariance of 𝑫𝑫\bm{D} and 𝑫′superscript𝑫bold-′\bm{D^{\prime}}, c1=(k1​H)2subscript𝑐1superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐻2c_{1}=\left(k_{1}H\right)^{2} and c2=(k2​H)2subscript𝑐2superscriptsubscript𝑘2𝐻2c_{2}=\left(k_{2}H\right)^{2} are constants with k1=0.01subscript𝑘10.01k_{1}=0.01, k2=0.03subscript𝑘20.03k_{2}=0.03, and H𝐻H being the dynamic range of the pixel-values.

5.2 Results for Image Data Reconstruction Attacks

To verify the feasibility and effectiveness of the proposed AWA method, we test it in image data reconstruction attacks and compared it with two state-of-the-art attack methods (AGIC xu2022agic and DLG zhu2019deep ) under the following four different FedAvg scenarios:

  • •

    Case 1: N=4𝑁4N=4, E=1𝐸1E=1, and B=1𝐵1B=1,

  • •

    Case 2: N=4𝑁4N=4, E=4𝐸4E=4, and B=1𝐵1B=1,

  • •

    Case 3: N=4𝑁4N=4, E=1𝐸1E=1, and B=4𝐵4B=4,

  • •

    Case 4: N=4𝑁4N=4, E=2𝐸2E=2, and B=2𝐵2B=2.

Recall the analysis in Section 3, when E>1𝐸1E>1 and B>1𝐵1B>1, the attacker has to use an approximate method for the attack. Therefore, only AWA and AGIC can conduct the attack for Case 4. The approximate strategy of each method is given below. Our proposed AWA method uses (20) to get the approximate intermediate model updates Δ​θ~t,eΔsubscript~𝜃𝑡𝑒\Delta\tilde{\theta}_{t,e} in each epoch e=1,2,…,E𝑒12…𝐸e=1,2,\ldots,E. Then, the attacker can reconstruct the client’s dataset by using any of the Δ​θ~t,eΔsubscript~𝜃𝑡𝑒\Delta\tilde{\theta}_{t,e} and the corresponding Gt,esubscript𝐺𝑡𝑒G_{t,e}. In Case 4 with E=2𝐸2E=2, we have two optional approximate intermediate model updates: Δ​θ~t,1Δsubscript~𝜃𝑡1\Delta\tilde{\theta}_{t,1} and Δ​θ~t,2Δsubscript~𝜃𝑡2\Delta\tilde{\theta}_{t,2}. In the test, we choose Δ​θ~t,1Δsubscript~𝜃𝑡1\Delta\tilde{\theta}_{t,1} as the target model update for the reconstruction. On the other hand, AGIC assumes that a combined batch consisting of all the mini-batches used in the client’s local training process can approximate the received model update in a single local update step. For this purpose, it initializes the dummy data with the same size as the combined mini-batches (N×E𝑁𝐸N\times E) and calculates the dummy model update by performing one local update step using the combined dummy data.

In all the tests, the DLG method utilizes the unweighted loss function (10) for the attack, while the AGIC method employs a weighted cosine similarity loss function by assigning linearly increasing weights to convolutional and fully connected layers. However, these weights are assigned empirically and not tailored case by case. In contrast, the AWA method employs the weighted and enhanced loss function (23) for the attack, with the layer weights determined by (24) and (27). The values of parameter Q𝑄Q are selected by utilizing the Bayesian optimization frazier2018tutorial . The cumulative minimum loss f​(Q)𝑓𝑄f(Q) of the Bayesian optimization in 50 trials are presented in Figure 1. It can be seen that the Bayesian optimization approach successfully finds a trend of smaller f​(Q)𝑓𝑄f(Q) values as the trial count increases. Then, the parameter settings in our AWA method for each case are listed in Table 3.

The numerical comparisons of the above three data reconstruction attack methods for Cases 1-4 are presented in Figure 2 and Table 4. We observe that in all four cases, our proposed AWA method consistently yields images with substantially enhanced resolution compared to those obtained by DLG and AGIC. This is further validated by the consistently highest values of PSNR and SSIM achieved by AWA in each case. Another noteworthy finding is the consistency in the reconstruction qualities of images produced by our AWA method across the diverse FedAvg cases, which demonstrates the robustness of our proposed approach.

In Case 4, where E>1𝐸1E>1 and B>1𝐵1B>1, DLG encounters difficulties in performing the attack due to the absence of an approximate strategy. On the other hand, although AGIC incorporates an approximate strategy, it fails to reconstruct images with identifiable objects effectively. In sharp contrast, the proposed AWA method demonstrates its capability to successfully reconstruct images with reasonable resolutions, overcoming the limitations faced by DLG and AGIC. Furthermore, the PSNR of images reconstructed in Case 4 is found to be comparable to that achieved in the first three cases, which strongly suggests the effectiveness of our proposed approximate strategy.

Furthermore, we implement the AWA method with 3000 iterations for four cases. All the other parameters maintain consistency with the original experiment setup. The resulting reconstructed images and the corresponding SSIM metrics for each case are represented in Figure 3. Evidently, the attained SSIM values surpass those presented in Table 4 for the 1000-iteration attack. The results clearly show a significant visual proximity between the reconstructed images and their original counterparts. Additionally, Figure 4 presents the evaluation metrics PSNR and SSIM, as well as the cumulative minimum value of the weighted loss during the attack across the four cases. It is evident that our method achieves a satisfactory level of reconstruction, with SSIM values exceeding 0.9 within 1500 attack iterations for all four cases. The outcomes of Case 4 exhibit a marginally inferior performance compared to Cases 1-3 due to the need of approximation. However, the reconstructed images in Case 4 remain sufficiently lucid to facilitate object identification. These results further validate the efficiency and effectiveness of our proposed AWA method.

Overall, the above results show the significant enhancement in reconstruction performance achieved by our proposed AWA method. The comprehensive evaluation provides strong evidence supporting the superiority of our method AWA in data reconstruction attacks for the considered FedAvg scenarios.

6 Conclusions

Although Federated Learning (FL) has emerged as a contemporary paradigm for safe distributed learning, its potential privacy benefits are compromised by data reconstruction attacks. In this paper, we first formulate the attack as an inverse problem (8), allowing us to reconstruct the client’s training data iteratively by solving an optimization problem (11). To attack the widely used FedAvg scenario, we propose an interpolation-based approximation method (20), where the intermediate model updates corresponding to each epoch are approximated by interpolating the model parameters. Furthermore, we propose a layer-wise weighted and enhanced loss function (23) for the attack to improve the quality of reconstructed data. By assigning appropriate weights to model updates in different layers solving (34), using the Bayesian optimization method, we achieve superior reconstruction results compared to the existing state-of-the-art methods. Moreover, our method is compatible with various neural network architectures like Convolutional Neural Networks and Residual Neural Networks. Numerical results validate that our proposed approximate and weighted data reconstruction attack method is effective for adversaries to exploit the vulnerabilities of FL systems utilizing Federated Averaging algorithms. The ability to reconstruct data from intermediate model updates highlights the need for robust defense mechanisms. Future research could focus on developing countermeasures and enhancing the security of FL frameworks to mitigate the risks associated with such attacks.
